chapters:
Welcome back to the Job Book How to Use Series.
If this is your first time watching,
remember that each episode builds on the last.

In the last video,
we exported invoices through the Invoice Process Backlog
so your accounting system stays synchronized with Job Book billing.

Today, we’re closing out the series.
We’ll review what we’ve covered,
talk about what comes next,
and highlight a few advanced Job Book features.

By now, you’ve learned how to:
Create clients and jobs.
Record Daily Work Records and expenses.
Use the Active Job Dashboard to monitor progress.
Approve DWRs, expenses, and invoices through the backlog system.
Create and send invoices.
Import them into your accounting system.

With these skills,
you can manage the full lifecycle of a job in Job Book—
from setup to invoicing.

Job Book stays reliable when everyone keeps information moving.
When technicians, coordinators, project managers, and administrators
stay on schedule, jobs stay profitable
and reporting stays trustworthy.

Daily Work Records and expenses keep the operational engine running.
Remind technicians that timely and accurate submissions
give you real-time visibility.

Project Managers should live in the Active Job Dashboard
for real-time status.

Watch labour, expenses, and budgets closely.
Drill into a job whenever actuals drift from the plan.
The dashboard converts Daily Work Records and expenses into insight—
so keep it bookmarked.

When it’s time to bill,
follow the pipeline we’ve built together.

Approved Daily Work Records flow into the DWR Invoice Backlog
for Time and Materials jobs.

Approved expenses appear alongside them for billable work.
Fixed-fee jobs depend on accurate setup—
keep milestone line items and billing schedules current.

From there, invoice creation, approval, and export
close the financial loop.

Staying in sequence prevents missed revenue
and keeps reconciliations painless.

Every stage connects to the next.
Clients and Jobs give structure to each transaction.
Daily Work Records and Expenses capture daily execution.
Approvals turn field data into billable output.
Invoices and Exports deliver accurate revenue to accounting.
Now that the core skills feel familiar, let’s look at what comes next.

The Job Book Reporting Guide Series 
shows how to use the built-in reports
to turn daily activity into insight.
Beyond reporting, Job Book includes modules that extend your workflows.

The Tasks and Scheduling module adds detailed team task tracking
and drag-and-drop scheduling.
The Leave module keeps vacation and sick time organized—no spreadsheets needed.

The Assets and Safety modules manage fleet maintenance, inspections,
and compliance records.

Each module follows the same principles you’ve practiced here—
clean setup, disciplined data entry, timely approvals, and consistent monitoring.

In the next training arc, we’ll turn to reporting so you can translate operational data
into insight for leadership, clients, and continuous improvement.

You now have the complete toolkit to manage daily work in Job Book with confidence.
Keep the momentum by reviewing your queues regularly, communicating with your teams,
and exploring the advanced modules that support your goals.

If you’re interested in in-depth reporting,
check out our Job Book Reporting Guide Series.

If you’d like to integrate with accounting or payroll systems,
watch our Job Book Integration Guide Series.

For setup and configuration, jump back to the Job Book Setup Guide Series.
Documentation is always available at getjobbook.com slash help.
And if you ever get stuck, our support team is only a phone call or email away.
That wraps up the Job Book How to Use Series.

Thanks for watching, and I’ll see you in the next series!
and don’t forget to subscribe for more Job Book updates
and helpful how-to videos!
